questions.text: Marker for ectopic pregnancy is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Beta hCG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beta hCG is the primary marker used to diagnose and manage ectopic pregnancies, providing essential information about pregnancy location and viability.
  • ➤ Beta hCG

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with shortness of breath, bilateral pitting pedal edema, and abdominal distension. On examination, jugular venous pulse was found to be elevated and liver was palpable 8 cm below the costal margin. An abnormality in which of the following structures is responsible for the patient's symptoms? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Right Ventricle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Right ventricular failure is characterized by systemic venous congestion, which manifests as elevated jugular venous pressure, pitting pedal edema, hepatomegaly, and abdominal distension. This condition is often seen in chronic smokers due to the impact of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) on the heart.
  • ➤ Right ventricular failure

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea presents to the OPD. She has Tanner stage IV secondary sexual characters. Her karyotype is 46XX. FSH is 5 and LH is 13. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mullerian agenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mullerian agenesis is a likely diagnosis in a patient with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual development, normal FSH/LH levels, and a 46XX karyotype.

questions.text: A male patient who was diagnosed with tuberculosis has successfully completed the full course of treatment. Subsequent to finishing both the intensive and continuation phases, the initial sputum examination was conducted. The results of this examination were negative. What is the current condition of the patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cured

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Terminologies:
  • ➤ Terminologies:
  • ➤ Cured - A TB patient whose smear or culture turned negative in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion Treatment completed - A TB patient who completed treatment without any failure, but has no record to show that sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion were negative; it may be either because tests were not done or because results are unavailable Treatment failed - A TB patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after treatment for 5 months or more Lost to follow-up - A TB patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for 2 consecutive months or more Died - A TB patient who dies before starting or during the course of treatment for any reason Not evaluated - A TB patient for whom no treatment outcome is assigned; this includes cases "transferred out" to another treatment unit and cases for whom the treatment outcome is unknown to the reporting unit whose treatment is interrupted
  • ➤ Cured - A TB patient whose smear or culture turned negative in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion
  • ➤ Cured -
  • ➤ Treatment completed - A TB patient who completed treatment without any failure, but has no record to show that sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion were negative; it may be either because tests were not done or because results are unavailable
  • ➤ Treatment completed -
  • ➤ Treatment failed - A TB patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after treatment for 5 months or more
  • ➤ Treatment failed -
  • ➤ Lost to follow-up - A TB patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for 2 consecutive months or more
  • ➤ Lost to follow-up
  • ➤ Died - A TB patient who dies before starting or during the course of treatment for any reason
  • ➤ Died -
  • ➤ Not evaluated - A TB patient for whom no treatment outcome is assigned; this includes cases "transferred out" to another treatment unit and cases for whom the treatment outcome is unknown to the reporting unit whose treatment is interrupted
  • ➤ Not evaluated -

questions.text: What is the blood supply of the structure marked with the arrow in the image below?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior cerebral artery and middle cerebral artery

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery

options.label: D
options.text: Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery

questions.correct_answer: C. Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The corpus callosum's blood supply is primarily provided by the anterior cerebral artery, with additional support from the anterior communicating artery. This knowledge is crucial in understanding potential impacts of circulatory issues within the brain, such as strokes, which could affect interhemispheric communication.

questions.text: Function of IL-8 is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Chemotaxis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary function of IL-8 is to induce chemotaxis, particularly attracting neutrophils to sites of infection or inflammation.

questions.text: A patient with history of alcoholism presented with right hypochondriac pain and fever. He had an episode of diarrhoea 1 week prior. USG abdomen reveals a liver abscess of around 25 cc in right lobe. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Medical management

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ For amoebic liver abscess, initial management should always begin with medical therapy using metronidazole, chloroquine, and diloxanide furoate. Drainage or aspiration is considered based on the size and risk of rupture of the abscess.
  • ➤ For amoebic liver abscess, initial management should always begin with medical therapy using metronidazole, chloroquine, and diloxanide furoate.
  • ➤ Drainage or aspiration is considered based on the size and risk of rupture of the abscess.

questions.text: A person working in a restaurant comes to the casualty with a huge burn on his abdomen. On examination, the injury looks like below. What is the most likely cause of the injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Moist heat

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most likely cause of the burn injury shown in the image is moist heat, specifically a scald injury caused by hot liquids or steam.
  • ➤ TYPES of SCALD INJURIES
  • ➤ TYPES of SCALD INJURIES
  • ➤ Immersion burns: Due to immersion in hot liquid, usually water. Accidental Splash burns Steam burns: Exposure to superheated steam.
  • ➤ Immersion burns: Due to immersion in hot liquid, usually water.
  • ➤ Immersion burns: Due to immersion in hot liquid, usually water.
  • ➤ Accidental Splash burns
  • ➤ Accidental Splash burns
  • ➤ Steam burns: Exposure to superheated steam.
  • ➤ Steam burns: Exposure to superheated steam.

questions.text: Mrs. Kumar, a 60-year-old woman, has been experiencing difficulty swallowing and a feeling of pressure in her chest. Her doctor orders an ultrasound, which reveals a retrosternal goiter. The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Neck

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via the neck. This is because the thyroid gland is anatomically located in the neck, and even when a goiter extends behind the sternum into the chest, the neck provides the most direct and least invasive access for surgical removal. The retrosternal portion of the goiter can usually be mobilized and delivered into the neck for excision without the need for more invasive thoracic approaches. The vascular supply of the goiter also predominantly comes from cervical vessels like the inferior thyroid artery, making the neck approach feasible and effective.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Chest: Surgical approaches through the chest are typically not used for retrosternal goiters. Accessing the thyroid gland through the chest would involve more invasive procedures, such as thoracotomy, and is generally reserved for rare cases with specific indications, such as very large goiters extending deeply into the chest cavity.
  • • Option B. Chest:
  • • Option C. Median Sternotomy: Median sternotomy involves cutting through the breastbone (sternum) to access structures within the chest, particularly the heart and major blood vessels. While median sternotomy is common for cardiac surgeries, it is not the primary approach for treating retrosternal goiters, which can typically be addressed via the neck.
  • • Option C. Median Sternotomy:
  • • Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because the neck is the commonest and preferred approach for the surgical removal of retrosternal goiters.
  • • Option D. None of the above:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common and preferred surgical approach for a retrosternal goiter is via the neck due to its direct access to the thyroid gland and the feasibility of mobilizing the goiter from this region.

questions.text: Epithelial lining of trachea is made of which type of cells? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pseudostratified ciliated columnar cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The trachea is lined with pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium, which plays a critical role in trapping and moving particles out of the respiratory system to keep the airways clear.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions Hamman’s sign can be appreciated? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Pneumomediastinum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hamman's sign, a crunching or crackling sound with each heartbeat, is associated with pneumomediastinum caused by the entry of air into the mediastinum.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presented with anemia. What is the most common cause? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iron deficiency anemia is the most common cause of anemia, especially in elderly patients, and requires thorough evaluation to rule out serious underlying conditions such as gastrointestinal malignancies.

questions.text: A 39-year-old G6P2L1A3 presents with a history of previous 2 LSCS with PAS. What will you NOT counsel her about? (INICET NOV 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS

options.label: C
options.text: Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS

questions.correct_answer: C. Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In cases of placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), the main risks include bleeding requiring transfusion, bladder injury, and possibly peripartum hysterectomy. Bowel injury is less commonly associated with PAS unless extreme or exceptional surgical complications occur.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Need for blood transfusion: It is common to counsel about the need for blood transfusion due to the high risk of hemorrhage.
  • • Option A. Need for blood transfusion:
  • • Option B. Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS: Bladder injury is a significant risk if the placenta invades the bladder area.
  • • Option B. Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS:
  • • Option D. Risk of peripartum hysterectomy: Peripartum hysterectomy may be necessary if the placenta is inseparable from the uterus.
  • • Option D. Risk of peripartum hysterectomy:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • When counseling a patient with a history of previous cesarean sections and PAS, focus on the more likely complications such as significant bleeding, bladder injury, and the possibility of needing a hysterectomy, rather than bowel injury.

questions.text: INSURE technique is used in newborn, born with which condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The INSURE technique (Intubate, Surfactant, Extubate) is primarily used in preterm infants with hyaline membrane disease to administer surfactant and improve lung function.

questions.text: Chronic alcoholic patient presented with confusion, Wernicke's aphasia and unstable gate. Patient has deficiency of: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vit B1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The symptoms described, including confusion, Wernicke's aphasia, and an unstable gait, are indicative of Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which is often associated with thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Chronic alcoholism can lead to poor nutritional intake and impaired absorption of essential nutrients, including thiamine. Thiamine is essential for the metabolism of glucose, and its deficiency can result in neurological symptoms.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 542
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 542

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to the ENT OPD with a complaint of nasal obstruction for the past two months. Her mother also reports foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On nasal endoscopy, the obstruction caused by crust formation is noted. She denies any bad smell. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Atrophic Rhinitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by chronic nasal obstruction, crust formation, and foul-smelling discharge. The patient’s denial of the bad smell indicates anosmia, which is common in atrophic rhinitis. This condition typically leads to the formation of crusts within the nasal cavity, causing obstruction and a foul odor noticed by others but not by the patient due to their reduced sense of smell.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Rhinitis Medicamentosa: This condition results from prolonged use of nasal decongestant drops (e.g., oxymetazoline or xylometazoline), leading to rebound nasal congestion, not crust formation or foul-smelling discharge.
  • • Option A. Rhinitis Medicamentosa:
  • • Option B. Rhinosporidiosis: Caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, it presents with polypoid masses in the nasal cavity but not with crust formation and foul-smelling discharge.
  • • Option B. Rhinosporidiosis:
  • • Option D. Rhinoscleroma : Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, it presents with a hard, woody nose and specific histopathological findings, not just crust formation and foul-smelling discharge.
  • • Option D. Rhinoscleroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atrophic rhinitis presents with chronic nasal obstruction, crust formation, and foul-smelling discharge, often accompanied by anosmia.

questions.text: An elderly lady presents with abdominal pain and distension. She has a history of chronic constipation. What is the most likely diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith

options.label: D
options.text: Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sigmoid volvulus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The abdominal X-ray shows a characteristic "coffee bean sign," which is indicative of a sigmoid volvulus. This radiological sign represents a massively distended sigmoid colon twisted on itself, resembling a bent tube or coffee bean. This condition is more common in elderly individuals, particularly those with a history of chronic constipation, due to the increased bowel length and mobility, combined with decreased bowel tone. Sigmoid volvulus can lead to severe abdominal pain and distension, as observed in this patient.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith: Typically presents with signs of obstruction but lacks the specific 'coffee bean' appearance associated with volvulus.
  • • Option B. Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith:
  • • Option C. Cecal volvulus: Would show a single dilated loop of bowel, often with haustrations, and generally appears in a different location and shape compared to the sigmoid volvulus.
  • • Option C. Cecal volvulus:
  • • Option D. Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation: Would likely show signs of free air under the diaphragm on an X-ray, which is not visible in the provided image.
  • • Option D. Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: An infant (given below in the image) presents to ophthalmology OPD with lacrimation and photophobia. What is the diagnosis. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Congenital Glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital Glaucoma should be suspected in infants presenting with photophobia, excessive tearing, and cloudy, enlarged corneas, as it is due to the abnormal development of the eye's drainage system leading to increased intraocular pressure.

questions.explanation: Ans. C) 1, 4

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap

  • ➤ Methanol intoxication causes metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap due to the accumulation of formic acid.

questions.text: Defect in which of the following essential amino acids metabolism can cause cardiac problems:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Methionine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B . Methionine: Correct Answer. Methionine metabolism defects can lead to homocystinuria, a condition characterized by elevated levels of homocysteine in the blood. High levels of homocysteine are associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases, such as thrombosis, atherosclerosis, and other vascular problems. The cardiac issues in homocystinuria are related to the damaging effects of high homocysteine levels on blood vessels.
  • • Option B
  • • Methionine:
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A . Tryptophan: Tryptophan is an essential amino acid involved in the synthesis of serotonin and niacin (Vitamin B3). Defects in tryptophan metabolism are more likely to affect neurological and mental health, rather than directly causing cardiac problems.
  • • Option A
  • • Tryptophan:
  • • Option C . Isoleucine: Isoleucine is a branched-chain amino acid, and while disorders in its metabolism (like Maple Syrup Urine Disease) can have serious health consequences, they are not typically known to directly cause cardiac problems. These conditions more commonly affect the nervous system and metabolic balance.
  • • Option C
  • • Isoleucine:
  • • Option D . Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine metabolism defects lead to phenylketonuria (PKU). While untreated PKU can lead to severe neurological problems due to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites, it does not primarily cause cardiac problems.
  • • Option D
  • • Phenylalanine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Defect in the metabolism of methionine can cause homocystinuria which is associated with high risk of cardiovascular disease. Classical homocystinuria is due to the deficiency of the enzyme, cystathionine beta Synthase. Clinical features : failure to thrive, developmental delay, ectopia lentis, severe myopia, cataracts, retinal detachment, and optic atrophy. Progressive mental retardation, skeletal abnormalities may resemble Marfan syndrome. Thromboembolic episodes may be seen at any age. Elevated homocysteine level is a risk factor for CAD, CVA, PAD and DVT.
  • ➤ Defect in the metabolism of methionine can cause homocystinuria which is associated with high risk of cardiovascular disease.
  • ➤ Classical homocystinuria is due to the deficiency of the enzyme, cystathionine beta Synthase.
  • ➤ cystathionine beta Synthase.
  • ➤ Clinical features : failure to thrive, developmental delay, ectopia lentis, severe myopia, cataracts, retinal detachment, and optic atrophy. Progressive mental retardation, skeletal abnormalities may resemble Marfan syndrome. Thromboembolic episodes may be seen at any age. Elevated homocysteine level is a risk factor for CAD, CVA, PAD and DVT.
  • ➤ Clinical features
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4326479/
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4326479/

questions.text: A patient has undergone laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Identify the structure as marked? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, it is crucial to identify the cystic artery and the cystic duct within Calot's triangle to prevent injury to the biliary structures and ensure a safe surgical procedure.

questions.text: Which of the following tissues are dependent on insulin for glucose uptake? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Muscle and adipose tissues

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • GLUT-4 glucose transporter is insulin dependent and is the only GLUT present in muscle and adipose tissues. So, muscles and adipose tissues are totally dependent on Insulin for glucose uptake.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Liver: The liver uses GLUT-2 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. GLUT-2 allows the liver to take up glucose and store it as glycogen or use it for energy production, independent of insulin.
  • • Option A. Liver:
  • • Option B. Pancreas: The pancreas also uses GLUT-2 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. In the pancreas, GLUT-2 plays a role in sensing blood glucose levels and regulating insulin secretion.
  • • Option B. Pancreas:
  • • Option D. Placenta: The placenta uses GLUT-1 and GLUT-3 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. These transporters facilitate the basal uptake of glucose to support the energy needs of the placenta and fetus.
  • • Option D. Placenta:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A woman has been diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Choose the correct statement? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source

options.label: B
options.text: Small blood vessels are most radioresistant

options.label: C
options.text: Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

options.label: D
options.text: Small intestinal mucosa is most radio-resistant

questions.correct_answer: A. Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Inverse Square Law is critical to understanding radiation dosage and safety in radiotherapy, ensuring that radiation exposure is managed correctly to maximize the therapeutic effect while minimizing harm to healthy tissues. This principle helps in planning and delivering radiation treatments effectively.

questions.text: Identify the type of epidemic.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Common intermittent source epidemic

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The graph shows cases occurring at irregular intervals with gaps between them, indicating that people are exposed intermittently to the source of infection. This pattern is characteristic of a common intermittent source epidemic , where exposures occur sporadically, leading to multiple peaks over time.
  • • common intermittent source epidemic
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Options A. Single exposure, point source epidemic: Characterized by a sudden rise and fall in the number of cases within a single incubation period, showing a single peak.
  • • Options A. Single exposure, point source epidemic:
  • • Options B. Multiple exposure, point source epidemic: Shows multiple peaks due to repeated exposures, but the rise and fall are not as sudden and are marked by secondary waves.
  • • Options B. Multiple exposure, point source epidemic:
  • • Options C. Propagated epidemic: Involves person-to-person transmission, typically showing a slow rise, a plateau, and a slow fall in the number of cases over time.
  • • Options C. Propagated epidemic:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A common intermittent source epidemic is marked by cases appearing at irregular intervals, reflecting intermittent exposures to the source of infection.

questions.text: What can be the mechanism by which phagolysosome cause cell death in autophagy? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: C. Fuses with lysosome to form autophagolysosome
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fuses with lysosome to form autophagolysosome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fusion of an autophagic vacuole with a lysosome to form an autophagolysosome is a central step in the autophagy process, enabling the degradation and recycling of cellular components.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 72
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 72

questions.text: A pregnant lady with 34 weeks of amenorrhea has the following findings: LDH - 700 IU/L, platelets - 75,000/ mm3, serum bilirubin - 1.5 mg/dL, SGOT - 200 U/L, SGPT - 150 U/L, and BP - 140/96 mm Hg. Her coagulation profile and renal function tests are normal. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)

questions.text: All are causes of uterine dysfunction, except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Multiparity

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Multiparity is not a cause of uterine dysfunction; rather, nulliparity (the condition of a woman who has never given birth) is a recognized cause. Uterine dysfunction, particularly hypotonic uterine dysfunction, is associated with several factors, but multiparity is generally associated with a more efficient labor process due to the body's previous experience with childbirth.
  • • Multiparity is not a cause of uterine dysfunction; rather, nulliparity (the condition of a woman who has never given birth) is a recognized cause. Uterine dysfunction, particularly hypotonic uterine dysfunction, is associated with several factors, but multiparity is generally associated with a more efficient labor process due to the body's previous experience with childbirth.
  • • Causes of hypotonic uterine dysfunction:
  • • Causes of hypotonic uterine dysfunction:
  • • Neuraxial analgesia : The use of epidural or spinal anesthesia can interfere with uterine contractions. Chorioamnionitis : This is an infection of the amniotic fluid and membranes, which can lead to inflammation and impaired uterine contractility. Nulliparity : First-time mothers (nulliparous women) are more likely to experience uterine dysfunction due to the unconditioned nature of the uterine muscles. Other factors : Mechanical disruption of myometrial function by a fibroid or pelvic tumor Maternal obesity Uterine mullerian anomaly Increased maternal age Malposition and malpresentation of the fetus Contracted pelvis
  • • Neuraxial analgesia : The use of epidural or spinal anesthesia can interfere with uterine contractions.
  • • Neuraxial analgesia
  • • Chorioamnionitis : This is an infection of the amniotic fluid and membranes, which can lead to inflammation and impaired uterine contractility.
  • • Chorioamnionitis
  • • Nulliparity : First-time mothers (nulliparous women) are more likely to experience uterine dysfunction due to the unconditioned nature of the uterine muscles.
  • • Nulliparity
  • • Other factors : Mechanical disruption of myometrial function by a fibroid or pelvic tumor Maternal obesity Uterine mullerian anomaly Increased maternal age Malposition and malpresentation of the fetus Contracted pelvis
  • • Other factors
  • • Mechanical disruption of myometrial function by a fibroid or pelvic tumor Maternal obesity Uterine mullerian anomaly Increased maternal age Malposition and malpresentation of the fetus Contracted pelvis
  • • Mechanical disruption of myometrial function by a fibroid or pelvic tumor
  • • Maternal obesity
  • • Uterine mullerian anomaly
  • • Increased maternal age
  • • Malposition and malpresentation of the fetus
  • • Contracted pelvis
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. High fetal head station : High fetal head station can be associated with labor dystocia and uterine dysfunction as it may indicate issues with the descent of the baby.
  • • Option A. High fetal head station
  • • Option C. Multiparity : Neuraxial block (e.g., epidural) can interfere with effective uterine contractions, leading to uterine dysfunction.
  • • Option C. Multiparity
  • • Option D. Chorioamnionitis : Chorioamnionitis, an infection, can impair uterine contractions and lead to dysfunctional labor.
  • • Option D. Chorioamnionitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nulliparity, not multiparity, is a cause of uterine dysfunction. Causes of hypotonic uterine dysfunction include neuraxial analgesia, chorioamnionitis, nulliparity, and mechanical factors such as fibroids or pelvic tumors.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg459, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg 416
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg459, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg 416

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient came with a history of fatiguability and constipation for the past 1 year. She has a history of multiple blood transfusions after delivery 4 years ago. She has had lactational failure and never regained her periods after the delivery. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sheehan syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Sheehan syndrome:
  • • Sheehan syndrome:
  • • The most probable diagnosis in a woman with lactational failure and postpartum amenorrhea, now presenting with fatiguability and constipation, is Sheehan syndrome. Sheehan syndrome refers to panhypopituitarism occurring as a result of pituitary ischemia and necrosis following massive obstetrical hemorrhage. The history of multiple blood transfusions after delivery indicates significant blood loss, which resulted in pituitary ischemia leading to this condition. Symptoms such as fatiguability and constipation can be attributed to secondary hypothyroidism resulting from pituitary dysfunction.
  • • The most probable diagnosis in a woman with lactational failure and postpartum amenorrhea, now presenting with fatiguability and constipation, is Sheehan syndrome.
  • • Sheehan syndrome refers to panhypopituitarism occurring as a result of pituitary ischemia and necrosis following massive obstetrical hemorrhage.
  • • The history of multiple blood transfusions after delivery indicates significant blood loss, which resulted in pituitary ischemia leading to this condition.
  • • Symptoms such as fatiguability and constipation can be attributed to secondary hypothyroidism resulting from pituitary dysfunction.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Hypothyroidism : While hypothyroidism can cause fatiguability and constipation, the history of postpartum amenorrhea and lactational failure makes Sheehan syndrome more likely. In Sheehan syndrome, hypothyroidism is a secondary consequence of pituitary dysfunction.
  • • Option B. Hypothyroidism
  • • Option C. Premature ovarian failure : Premature ovarian failure typically presents with symptoms of estrogen deficiency such as hot flashes and vaginal dryness, along with amenorrhea. However, it does not account for the history of significant postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure seen in this patient.
  • • Option C. Premature ovarian failure
  • • Option D. Delayed blood transfusion reaction : Delayed blood transfusion reactions usually present with symptoms such as jaundice, fever, and anemia, but they do not explain the chronic symptoms of fatiguability, constipation, lactational failure, and amenorrhea in this patient.
  • • Option D. Delayed blood transfusion reaction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sheehan syndrome is characterized by panhypopituitarism due to pituitary ischemia and necrosis following massive obstetrical hemorrhage, leading to symptoms such as lactational failure, amenorrhea, fatiguability, and constipation.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 465, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 465, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: What is the most common route of the spread of retinoblastoma? ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Direct invasion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Direct invasion is the primary method of spread for retinoblastoma is essential in recognizing how the tumor progresses and impacts surrounding ocular structures. This knowledge is crucial for effective screening, early diagnosis, and management to prevent advanced stages of disease and potential metastasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in making a diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder includes impairments in social interaction, social communication, and restrictive, repetitive behaviors, but not cognitive dysfunction.

questions.text: Identify the transporter of iodine from follicular cells to follicular cavity within the thyroid gland: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pendrin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pendrin is the transporter responsible for moving iodine from the follicular cells into the colloid of the thyroid gland, a crucial step in thyroid hormone production.

questions.text: Given below is an X-ray of shoulder of a 25-year-old male who suffered a shoulder injury and now exhibits swelling around the shoulder joint. Based on the X-ray, which structure(s) is/are probable sites of injury? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.correct_answer: A. Both acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligament
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Both acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligament

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In acromioclavicular joint dislocation or separation, as shown in the image provided in the question, there is tear in the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.

questions.text: Reiter's syndrome is associated with: ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HLA B27

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Reiter's syndrome, also known as reactive arthritis, is strongly associated with the HLA-B27 antigen. This association is part of a broader category of diseases called seronegative spondyloarthropathies. The key conditions linked with HLA-B27 include:
  • • Ankylosing Spondylitis : This condition has the highest association with HLA-B27. Psoriatic Arthritis : A form of arthritis that affects some people with psoriasis. Reactive Arthritis (Reiter's Syndrome) : Characterized by a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. Enteropathic Arthritis : Associated with inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.
  • • Ankylosing Spondylitis : This condition has the highest association with HLA-B27.
  • • Ankylosing Spondylitis
  • • Psoriatic Arthritis : A form of arthritis that affects some people with psoriasis.
  • • Psoriatic Arthritis
  • • Reactive Arthritis (Reiter's Syndrome) : Characterized by a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis.
  • • Reactive Arthritis (Reiter's Syndrome)
  • • Enteropathic Arthritis : Associated with inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.
  • • Enteropathic Arthritis
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. HLA B51 : It is linked with Behçet's disease.
  • • Option A. HLA B51
  • • Option C. HLA DR4 : Associated with rheumatoid arthritis.
  • • Option C. HLA DR4
  • • Option D. HLA B8 : Associated with diseases such as myasthenia gravis and celiac disease.
  • • Option D. HLA B8

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ Reiter's syndrome is part of the seronegative spondyloarthropathies and is strongly associated with the HLA-B27 antigen.

questions.text: What is the karyotype associated with this finding? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 47, XY (+21)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Down syndrome (trisomy 21) is the most common non-preventable cause of intellectual disability and is associated with characteristic physical findings such as a single palmar crease.

questions.text: A female presented in dermatology OPD with acne that is not resolving on oral isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy. Which of the following is the next best step among the following options? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Evaluate for hyperandrogenism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When faced with a female patient whose acne has not improved with oral isotretinoin and antibiotics , the next best step is to evaluate f or hyperandrogenism, which can point to an underlying hormonal cause such as PCOS , necessitating a different treatment approach.
  • ➤ female patient
  • ➤ acne
  • ➤ not improved
  • ➤ isotretinoin
  • ➤ antibiotics
  • ➤ evaluate f
  • ➤ hyperandrogenism,
  • ➤ hormonal
  • ➤ PCOS

References:

  • ↳ References: Williams Gynaecology 4 th edition: page no 392-394

questions.text: In Pompe’s disease, enzyme deficiency is? ( INICET May 2023
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lysosomal acid alpha glucosidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In individuals with Pompe's disease, the deficiency of lysosomal acid alpha glucosidase leads to the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly the muscles. This glycogen buildup affects the proper functioning of cells and tissues, causing a wide range of symptoms, primarily affecting the muscles and respiratory system.
